30/60-day plan (example for an ambiguous, outcome-driven role):
• Days 1–7: Align on 1–2 highest-impact problems, define success metrics + baseline (e.g., cycle time, conversion, cost, SLA), map stakeholders/owners, and create a weekly update cadence.
• Days 8–30: Ship one “thin-slice” deliverable to de-risk execution (MVP or process change) with clear measurement. Deliver: written PRD/one-pager, execution plan, risk register, and a dashboard or simple metric tracker. Goal: measurable movement on the primary metric + clear learnings.
• Days 31–60: Expand to full solution + operationalize. Deliver: v2 rollout, documentation, handoff/runbook, and stakeholder review. Goal: sustain improvement and reduce ongoing oversight (clear ownership + monitoring).

Two examples of ambiguous work → measurable outcomes:
1) Took an unclear cross-functional problem with multiple stakeholders, scoped it into a 2-phase plan, ran weekly alignment, and delivered the first shippable increment within ~3 weeks; result was a measurable improvement in the target KPI and a repeatable process others could follow.
2) Owned an end-to-end workflow with unclear requirements, created a lightweight metric baseline, prioritized the highest-leverage fixes, and drove the project through delivery with minimal oversight; result was faster turnaround and fewer escalations due to clearer ownership and communication.
